user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of producer_thread:
```c
static void *producer_thread(void *arg)
{
	(void)arg;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&lock);
	while (counter == COUNTER_MAX)
		metal_condition_wait(&nfull_condv, &lock);
	counter++;
	metal_condition_signal(&nempty_condv);
	metal_mutex_release(&lock);

	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function producer_thread:
int metal_condition_wait(struct metal_condition *cv,
				       metal_mutex_t *m)
{
	uintptr_t tmpmptr = 0, mptr = (uintptr_t)m;
	int v = 0;

	/* Check if the mutex has been acquired */
	if (!cv || !m || !metal_mutex_is_acquired(m))
		return -EINVAL;

	if (!atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&cv->mptr, &tmpmptr, mptr)) {
		if (tmpmptr != mptr)
			return -EINVAL;
	}

	v = atomic_load(&cv->wakeups);
	atomic_fetch_add(&cv->waiters, 1);

	/* Release the mutex before sleeping. */
	metal_mutex_release(m);
	syscall(SYS_futex, &cv->wakeups, FUTEX_WAIT, v, NULL, NULL, 0);
	atomic_fetch_sub(&cv->waiters, 1);
	/* Acquire the mutex after it's waken up. */
	metal_mutex_acquire(m);

	return 0;
}
...
METAL_MUTEX_DEFINE(lock)
...
static struct metal_condition nfull_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static struct metal_condition nempty_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static unsigned int counter
...
#define COUNTER_MAX 10
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter variables are assigned or otherwise modified in the provided code fragments, so there are no violations of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 to investigate. Details:

- producer_thread(void *arg): The only use of the parameter is the discard cast (void)arg; which is not a modification of the parameter. The function does not assign to arg or change the pointer value.

- metal_condition_wait(struct metal_condition *cv, metal_mutex_t *m): Neither cv nor m is assigned to anywhere in the function. Operations that occur are:
  - Reading the pointers in checks (if (!cv || !m ...)) — permitted.
  - Casting m to an integer into a separate local (mptr = (uintptr_t)m) — this creates/modifies a local variable, not the parameter.
  - atomic_compare_exchange_strong mutates the local tmpmptr and potentially the object pointed to by cv (cv->mptr), but it does not assign to the parameter variable cv itself. Modifying the object pointed to by a pointer parameter is allowed by the rule.
  - metal_mutex_release(m) and metal_mutex_acquire(m) operate on the object pointed to by m (allowed); they do not change the parameter variable m.
  - atomic_fetch_add/sub operate on fields of *cv (allowed) and do not modify the parameter variable.

Because none of the function parameter identifiers (arg, cv, m) are assigned a new value in these fragments, there are no suspicious code fragments with respect to Rule 17.8.
